story:
Thank you for supporting my fundraising for Macmillan Cancer Support. 

With both my Mummy and Granny in ongoing treatment for breast cancer, this is a cause hugely close to my family's heart. 

To help Breast Cancer Awareness over this month, and for the vital Macmillan Cancer Support, I will be walking 2 marathons across 8 days - a marathon for each of the two most important and fabulous women in my life. I will be walking 10.5km every morning before work - come rain, snow or shine - from Thursday 15th until Thursday 22nd October. 

Your support will energise me and my head torch in the dark along the way.

Macmillan nurses are an essential, professional comforting support to so many battling cancer and to their families. Macmillan Cancer Support helps everyone to live with cancer as fully as they are able, and supports the family and the patient every step of the way. Hence, I'm walking...!

As a result of COVID-19, this year is exceptionally challenging for us all, but if there was any way that you could spare even the smallest donation for the continuing work of this wonderful organisation then I would be so grateful. The only way Macmillan nurses and Macmillan Cancer Support exist and continue to provide such help, is through our recognition and funding.

Thank you very much. 

Love, Juliet xxx

On 30th October 1978 Julie Gardner started work at Delta Enfield Rolling Mills where I was working. On 14th February 1979 we got engaged and were married on 8th September 1979. Four wonderful children came along - Janine in 1984, Daryl in 1986, Stephen in 1990 and Andrew in 1992. During that time we moved from Ware to Stevenage to Bedford where we have lived since 1991. In 2019 we celebrated our Ruby wedding anniversary.

In September 2001 at just 42 years of age Julie was diagnosed with breast cancer. After a mastectomy and radiotherapy she was eventually given the all clear in 2008. However in September 2010 Julie was diagnosed with secondary breast cancer - the same strain of cancer had returned but this time in her stomach area. An immediate course of chemotherapy followed and again in 2016 along with more radiotherapy all in an effort to keep the disease at bay for as long as possible. By this time we knew it couldn't be cured. The pain and stress was only really lightened by seeing our children growing up and getting married and the arrival of our fabulous grandchildren - Harry in 2014, Rose in 2016, Stanley in 2017 and Arthur in 2018. A fifth is due in February 2021.

In January this year Julie's condition worsened considerably and in June we were told there was nothing more that could be done. On Friday 24th July Julie, at just 61 years of age, passed away. 

During her last few months with us the MacMillan Cancer Support people were fantastic and I really do not know what we would have done without them. It is entirely thanks to them that Julie got her wish and when she passed away it was at our home surrounded by her loving family.

In recent years we became enamoured by the Suffolk seaside town of Southwold and went there at least two or three times a year. For the past three years we have spent Christmas in Southwold, hiring a big house so that all the family can come and spend Christmas together. We are booked to go again this Christmas, 

On Christmas Day there is an annual Southwold Christmas Day swim in the sea for charity. Sadly this year it has been cancelled due to Covid-19 but I will be doing my own personal swim in the sea on Christmas Day and am doing so to try and raise as much money as I can for MacMillan Cancer Support. I am doing it for them and in memory of my beautiful wife Julie (aka Jude) who meant the world to me and always will. Wife, Mum and Grandma.

Always and Forever. x

story:
On 24th October myself and 3 friends, Paul, Kev and Andy will be competing in the Battle Cancer UK City League event held at our local gym 'Go Train East Rock'. We will complete two gruelling 9 minute wods with only a few minutes rest between them. This is a team event so all 4 members are working at the same time.

We have chosen to raise money for Macmillan Cancer Support because of the amazing work that they do. At the beginning of this year my father-in-law, Stuart was diagnosed with cancer and gratefully he is now in recovery. This is what Stuart had to say about them;

 "Before, during and continuing now in my recovery I have had amazing support from a Macmillan sponsored specialist nurse at Raigmore Hospital. She was aware of all that I was going through and was at hand whenever I needed a question answered or an issue that I was struggling with.

Without the support of Macmillan Cancer Support I would have been unlikely to have such professional and caring support all of which helped me through what, to date, has been the most challenging time of my life".

So thanks for supporting our fundraising. Macmillan Cancer Support is here to help everyone with cancer live life as fully as they can, providing physical, financial and emotional support. So whatever cancer throws your way, they’re right there with you.

eventName: In memory of Leslie John Lane
story:
Leslie John Lane passed away last week aged 90 years old.  He had travelled from Tottenham in the late 1940s to start a job as a Telegram Delivery Boy.   He was motivated, hardworking and had the ability to always remember how difficult it was to have come through the Second World War as an evacuee.  He was a smart young man who enjoyed the fashion industry.  An ability to make people comfortable led him to becoming a Manager in a Men's clothing store near Barclay Square.  A wonderful opportunity arose and his skills with people of walks of life brought him back to Tottenham where he became the Building Control Manager.   He was well respected and always wanted to support his community.



As he got older his health deteriorated due to heart disease.  Heart Disease is one of the world's leading causes of death.  In the UK, there are around 7.4 million people living with heart and circulatory disease in the UK: 3.9 million men and 3.5 million women.   Coronary Heart Disease (CHD) is the most common type of heart and circulatory disease according to the British Heart Foundation.

Leslie, as he got older, lost his hearing, his mobility and gradually his sight.  He had such an appreciation for life, occupied his mind with thoughts for others when he woke and thoughts for his loved ones just before he slept.   He never complained, no matter how tough life became, appreciating the good in every moment.  Though with all of his ailments the only thing he wished for was that his heart would be just a little better so he could travel or be able to visit friends and family spending quality time to occupy his later years.  Life did become lonely for him despite a close family and friends network.

Leslie asked that after he passed people who wanted to remember him make a donation to British Heart Foundation specifically for funding life-saving research to provide care for people in your community and across the nation.  As a public servant for over 25 years he greatly appreciated the men and women who provided for him; moreover if we could find a cure for Heart Disease then that would be even more wonderful.

Leslie was a rock for others, stable, consistent, dependable and relentless in his love and how he loved, with his heart.

Every little bit does help, please donate generously in the memory of Leslie. J. Lane and no doubt he will thank you!

eventName: Yorkshire Three Peaks and UK Three Peaks in honour of Ted Campbell
story:
On 18th January 2020, my life changed forever as my father who was loved by so many passed away, leaving behind a wife, 6 children, 5 grandchildren and so many friends.

If I'm honest, this had a such a huge impact on myself and led me to go what I would call a bit 'off the rails', turning to bad habits far too often and leading myself down a very slippery slope that would end in the very worst possible way.

After one weekend, I felt so awful about what I was doing not only to myself, but my family, my work...pretty much everyone and decided I needed to change and fast.

That was in August 2020 and I had never felt so low. I thankfully turned to people for help and with a little encouragement, have got myself back on track and I've since led a much healthier lifestyle that I give thanks to so many people for.

I've decided that I'd like to turn the impact of losing my old man into a positive one by challenging myself more than ever before in his honour for a cause that meant so much to him.

In November 2020, I'll be taking part in the Yorkshire Three Peaks Challenge and in March 2021, I'll be taking part in the UK Three Peaks Challenge. I'll be staying sober for the duration and all proceeds raised from this will be going to the British Heart Foundation.

Absolutely any donation will mean the World to me and more! I've never been more motivated to do anything in my entire life and I promise not to let any of you down.

It's been such a tough year but I'm determined to end it on a high going into 2021 and make the greatest man I'll ever know and my family proud.

Dates:

  • Yorkshire - 14th November 2020
  • UK - 13th March 2021

Some info here on the life changing work that The British Heart Foundation does and what your donation will go to:
https://www.justgiving.com/britishheartfoundation 

Thanks for visiting my page,

Michael x

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Thanks for taking the time to visit our Just Giving Page. We are looking to raise money for Cancer Research UK as our Dad/Taid had a very rare malignant tumour which needs more research to help cure the condition. 

About 2 1/2 years ago our Dad/Taid started to experience headaches. He had a number of necessary tests and scans which eventually diagnosed him with a pituitary tumour. 

A few months after he had an operation in Manchester hospital to remove the tumour, but unfortunately the aggressive nature of the tumour it grew to double the size in just 6 weeks. He underwent 5 weeks of radiotherapy in Christie’s hospital in Manchester. After 6 months the tumour grew again and he was then diagnosed with a very rare malignant pituitary tumour. 

From a strong physically working man within 6 months Dad/Taid was unable to do daily tasks without support. On 6th October 2020 he sadly lost his fight. 

Our amazing Dad/Taid was strong, kind, considerate and determined man. He remained positive throughout, he did not moan once and has only ever been concerned about his wife, children and grandchildren. 

Any amount that you can give to help us continue to fight against Cancer would be greatly appreciated.

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

Many of you may know that our much loved mum passed away peacefully with us all by her side recently. 

We had the privilege of caring for her at home until the end, however this would never have been possible if it wasn’t for the warmth and kindness of the Marie Curie  angels that got us through the night. 

Each of them personalised their relationship with us and became invaluable towards the end. Words cannot begin to articulate our appreciation, but we do know that with mum passing away, these angels can support another family in the way they did us. 

It costs the charity £160 per evening on average to support a family and we would like to raise at least enough money to pay for two evenings, so loved ones can sleep in the knowledge their relative is safe in their care.

With love, 

Lorna, Charles & Paul
